data.title: Black History Month: Black Pennsylvania athletes who excelled
data.meta_description: These black Pennsylvanian athletes have left their mark in football, baseball and basketball.
data.text:
These black Pennsylvania athletes have left their mark in football, baseball and basketball.

Herb Adderley, cornerback for the Dallas Cowboys, is shown in September 1972. (AP Photo)

Herb Adderley

Herb Adderley was born in 1939 in Philadelphia. He was a professional football player for the Green Bay Packers and Dallas Cowboys. He was inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1980.

Dick Allen Philadelphia Phillies 3B rookie on March 1964 at Florida training camp. (AP Photo)

Dick Allen

Dick Allen was born in 1942 in Wampum, Lawrence County. He played professional baseball for the Philadelphia Phillies and Chicago White Sox. He was Rookie of the Year in 1964, a seven-time All-Star and the 1972 American League MVP. After retiring from baseball he came a professional singer.

Los Angeles Lakers forward Kobe Bryant, left, works against Utah Jazz guard Shelvin Mack during the first half of an NBA basketball game, Wednesday, April 13, 2016, in Los Angeles. (AP Photo/Mark J. Terrill)

Kobe Bryant

Kobe Bryant was born in 1978 in Philadelphia. He was a professional basketball player with the L.A. Lakers for 20 years. He was named an All-Star 18 times. He also was a member of the All-NBA Team 15 times and a member of the All-Defensive Team 12 times. He holds the NBA record for the most seasons played with one franchise for an entire career.

Brooklyn Dodger catcher Roy Campanella goes down on one knee as he connects with ball in one of his unorthodox swings, August 30, 1955. (AP Photo)

Roy Campanella (1921-1993)

Campanella made his major league baseball debut in 1948 with the Brooklyn Dodgers. His career was ended when he was paralyzed in a car accident in January 1958. He was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1969 and is considered by some to be one of the best catchers in the history of baseball. He was born in Philadelphia.

Philadelphia 76ers' Fred Carter (3), grimaces as he drives around Boston Celtics' Dave Cowens, in their National Basketball Association game on Friday, Nov. 14, 1975, at Boston Garden. Philadelphia won the game 119 to 109. (AP Photo/PRS)

Fred Carter

Fred Carter was born in 1945 in Philadelphia. He was drafted in the third round in 1969. Carter played for the Baltimore Bullets, Philadelphia 76ers and Milwaukee Bucks. He was a basketball analyst for ESPN and co-host of "The NBA 2Night." He was the first African-American student at Mount St. Mary's University. He was a coach of the Mount St. Mary's women's team 1978-81, and later assistant coach for the Atlantic Hawks, Chicago Bulls, Washington Bullets and 76ers. He was coach of the 76ers in 1993 and 1994..

Wilt Chamberlain leaps high to grab a rebound for Kansas, December 26, 1956. Identifiable Iowa State players are Chuck Vogt (41) left and Gary Davis (31). At extreme right is Ronald Johnson (18) of Kansas. Kansas won the first round Big Seven Basketball Tournament game 58-57. (AP Photo/William Straeter)

Wilt Chamberlain (1936-1999)

Chamberlain scored 100 points in a single basketball game and the record still stands. It happened on March 2, 1962, when the Philadelphia Warriors were playing at Hershey Sports Arena. Chamberlain was named to the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1979. He was born in Philadelphia.

New Orleans Saints wide receiver Marques Colston (12) scores a touchdown reception on Detroit Lions cornerback Nevin Lawson (24) in the second half of an NFL football game in New Orleans, Monday, Dec. 21, 2015. (AP Photo/Brynn Anderson)

Marques Colson

Colston played football at Susquehanna Twp. High School and Hofstra University before the NFL. In the NFL he played for the New Orleans Saints until 2015. He was the majority owner of the Harrisburg Stampede indoor football team.

Ernie Davis, halfback for Syracuse, holds the Heisman Memorial Trophy prior to official presentation to him in New York City on Dec. 6, 1961. Davis is the first black athlete to receive the nation's outstanding college football player award. (AP Photo)

Ernie Davis (1939-1963)

Davis was a football player and the first African-American to win the Heisman Trophy in 1961. He played for Syracuse University and was the first pick in the 1962 NFL Draft. He was drafted by the Washington Redskins then immediately traded to the Cleveland Browns. In 1962 he was diagnosed with the leukemia and died less than a year later at the age of 23. He was born in New Salem.

FILE - In this Aug. 15, 2014, file photo, Pennsylvania's Mo'ne Davis delivers in the fifth inning against Tennessee during a baseball game at the Little League World Series tournament in South Williamsport, Pa. Davis was the talk of the sports world and beyond after becoming the first female to win a game in the Little League World Series. (AP Photo/Gene J. Puskar, File)

Mo'ne Davis

Davis was one of two girls to play in the 2014 Little League World Series and the first girl to earn a win and to pitch a shutout in Little League World Series history. She was the first African-American girl to play in the Little League World Series and the first Little League baseball player to appear on the cover of Sports Illustrated. She was born in 2001 in Philadelphia.

University of Pittsburgh running-back Tony Dorsett trots through the end-zone after scoring a touchdown on a 40-yard screen pass and run in the second period of Pittsburgh game with Miami, Fla., Saturday, October 17, 1976. (AP Photo)

Tony Dorsett

Dorsett played football at the University of Pittsburgh and won the Heisman Trophy in 1976. He played in the NFL for the Dallas Cowboys and Denver Broncos. He was named to the Pro Football Hall of Fame and the College Football Hall of Fame. Dorsett was born in 1954 in Rochester.

Loyola Marymount basketball player Hank Gathers poses before practice at the university's gym in Los Angeles on Feb. 15, 1990. Gathers who won on his way to becoming only the second player in NCAA history to lead the nation in both scoring and rebounding. (AP Photo/Douglas C. Pizac)

Hank Gathers (1967-1990)

Gathers was a basketball player at Loyola Marymount University when he collapsed and died during a game on March 4, 1990, in Los Angeles. He was the second player in NCAA Division I history to lead the nation in scoring and rebounding in the same season. It was determined that Gathers had a heart muscle disorder. He was born in Philadelphia.

File - Ohio State's Eddie George (27) is shown in this 1995 file photo in Columbus, Ohio. (AP Photo/Mark Hall)

Eddie George

George is a professional football player. He won the Heisman Trophy when he played at Ohio State University. He went on to play for the Tennessee Titans and was inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame in 2011. In 2016 he appeared in the musical "Chicago" on Broadway. George was born in 1973 in Philadelphia.

Seattle Mariner Ken Griffey Sr. watches as his three-run homer sails into the stands during fourth inning against the Oakland Athletics in Seattle, Sept. 11, 1990. Seattle beat Oakland 5-2. (AP Photo/Jim Davidson)

Ken Griffey Sr.

Ken Griffey Sr. was a professional baseball player from Donora, Washington County. He played with the Cincinnati Reds, New York Yankees, Atlanta Braves and Seattle Mariners. Griffey was a three-time All-Star. He was born in 1950 and is the father of Ken Griffey Jr., also a professional baseball player.

Ken Griffey Jr. of the Seattle Mariners collects a double off pitcher Scott Erickson of the Minnesota Twins during the third inning in Seattle, July 30, 1993. (AP Photo/Gary Stewart)

Ken Griffey Jr.

Ken Griffey Jr. was a professional baseball player for 22 years primarily with the Seattle Mariners and Cincinnati Reds. He is a member of the Baseball Hall of Fame and has the seventh most home runs with 630. He was named an All-Star 13 times. He was born in 1969 in Donora, Washington County.

** FILE ** Indianapolis Colts receiver Marvin Harrison (88) talks to quarterback Peyton Manning (18) after the Colts' 28-23 win over the Cleveland Browns, Dec. 15, 2002, in Cleveland. Harrison and Manning are now the authors of the NFL's how-to manual on flawless play. (AP Photo/Ron Schwane)

Marvin Harrison

Marvin Harrison was born in 1972 in Philadelphia. He played in the NFL for the Indianapolis Colts until 2008. He was elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 2016.

Joanna Hayes clears a hurdle in the third heat of the women's 110 meter hurdles quarterfinals at the U.S. Olympic Track and Field Trials in Eugene, Ore., Saturday, July 5, 2008. (AP Photo/Eric Gay)

Joanna Hayes

Hayes was born in 1976 in Williamsport. She won a gold medal in the 100-meter hurdles at the 2004 Summer Olympics. She was inducted into the UCLA Athletics Hall of Fame in October 2014.

Oakland Athletics right fielder Reggie Jackson blasts his 29th homer of the season in Oakland, Calif., on June 30, 1969 in the fifth inning of the second game against Chicago's White Sox in Oakland, Ca. (AP Photo)

Reggie Jackson

Jackson was born in 1946 in Wyncote, Montgomery County. A professional baseball player, he played for the Kansas City/Oakland Athletics, Baltimore Orioles, New York Yankees and California Angels. He was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1993.

Leroy Kelly of the Cleveland Browns speeds through a crowd of Washington Redskins on a 21-yard touchdown run, Nov. 26, 1967. Washington defensive back Paul Krause, far left, got a straight arm moments after this picture was taken, and Kelly dived into the end zone. Other identifiable players include Redskins Walter Barnes (77) Carl Kammerer (66) and Ralph Smith (41) of the Browns. (AP Photo)

Leroy Kelly

Kelly was a professional football player for the Cleveland Browns. He was named to six Pro Bowls and in 1994 was named to the Pro Football Hall of Fame. Kelly was born in 1942 in Philadelphia.

Maurice Lucas of the Portland Trail Blazers goes up with ball against Larry Bird of the Boston Celtics during first period action in Boston, Jan. 18, 1980. (AP Photo/Dave Tenenbaum)

Maurice Lucas (1952-2010)

Lucas was a professional basketball player in the American Basketball Association with the Spirit of St. Louise and the Kentucky Colonels. He also played 12 seasons in the NBA with the Portland Trail Blazers, New Jersey Nets, New York Knickerbockers, Phoenix Suns, Los Angeles Lakers and Seattle SuperSonics. He was nicknamed "The Enforcer" and was born in Pittsburgh.

Baltimore Bullets' guard Earl Monroe scrambles after the ball while guarded by New York Knicks' Walt Frazier in the first quarter of the NBA's Eastern Division semi-final playoff in Baltimore, Md., April 5, 1970. New York's Bill Bradley watches in background. (AP Photo/Bob Schutz)

Earl Monroe

Earl "The Pearl" Monroe played basketball for the Baltimore Bullets and the New York Knicks. As a student at Winston-Salem State University in 1967 he was the NCAA College Division Player of the Year. He was the second overall draft pick and was named NBA Rookie of the Year playing for the Bullets. He scored 56 points in a game against the Lakers, the third-highest rookie total in NBA history. He was born in Philadelphia.

Lenny Moore Baltimore Colt halfback (24) managed a first down on this run, but was overhauled by two pursuing Green Bay Packers, Willie Wood (24) and Hank Gremminger (46), Nov. 19, 1962, Green Bay, Wisc. The action occurred in the 1st period. (AP Photo/Charles Kelly)

Lenny Moore

Moore played football at Penn State University and in the NFL for the Baltimore Colts. He was NFL Rookie of the Year in 1956 and was selected to the Pro Bowl seven times. Moore was elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1975. He was born in Reading in 1933.

Orlando Magic guard Jameer Nelson (14) drives past Charlotte Bobcats guard Raymond Felton (20) during the first half of an NBA basketball game in Orlando, Fla., Saturday, Nov. 18, 2006. (AP Photo/Phelan M. Ebenhack)

Jameer Nelson

Nelson, a professional basketball player, was born in 1982 in Chester. He was named the national college player of the year in 2004. He played for 10 years with the Orlando Magic then the Dallas Mavericks, Boston Celtics, Denver Nuggets, New Orleans Pelicans and Detroit Pistons.

Billy Owens plays in Hershey with Syracuse University, Dec. 20, 1990. (Allied Pix for The Patriot-News)

Billy Owens

Owens played basketball at Carlisle High School, Syracuse University and in the NBA for the Golden State Warriors, Miami Heat, Sacramento Kings, Seattle SuperSonics, Philadelphia 76ers and Detroit Pistons. He was born in Carlisle in 1969.

The USA's Carl Lewis, center; Mike Powell, left; and Joe Greene, stand together on the podium during medal presentation ceremonies for the men's long jump at Barcelona's Olympic stadium Friday, August 7, 1992. Lewis took the gold, Powell the silver and Greene the bronze. (AP Photo/Dieter Endlicher)

Mike Powell

Powell was born in 1963 in Philadelphia. He won two silver medals at the 1992 Summer Olympics. Powell holds the world record for the long jump at 8.95 meters.

Knickerbockers Walt Bellamy takes long shot to basket, which he made, as Warriors Guy Rodgers (5), and Nate Thurmond watch during first period of game at the Oakland Auditorium in Oakland, California on Feb. 14, 1966. New York's Howard Komives (16) in background. (AP Photo)

Guy Rodgers (1935-2001)

Rodgers played for 12 years in the NBA with the Philadelphia Warriors, Chicago Bulls, Cincinnati Royals and Milwaukee Bucks. He was a four-time All-Star and won the Robert V. Geasey Trophy three times while at Temple University. He was born in Philadelphia.

Head coach Dawn Staley talks with players and assistant coaches during a practice for the U.S. national women's basketball team Tuesday, April 24, 2018, in Seattle. The team plays an exhibition game against China Thursday, April 26. (AP Photo/Elaine Thompson)

Dawn Staley

Staley was an WNBA player and was elected to the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame in 2013. She has three Olympic gold medals in basketball and was selected to carry the U.S. flag at the 2004 Summer Olympics. She coached at Temple University and has been the head women's basketball coach at the University of South Carolina since 2008. She was born in Philadelphia in 1970.

Source unknown

Willie Thrower (1930-2002)

Thrower, a football quarterback, was nicknamed "Mitts" because of his large hands. He was the first African-American quarterback in professional football. He played for Michigan State and the Chicago Bears. Thrower was born in New Kensington, Westmoreland County.

Portland Trail Blazers' forward Rasheed Wallace dunks the ball during a game against the New Jersey Nets, in Portland, Ore., Tuesday, March 4, 1997. (AP Photo/Jack Smith)

Rasheed Wallace

Wallace played 16 seasons in the NBA for the Washington Bullets, Portland Trail Blazers, Atlanta Hawks, Detroit Pistons, Boston Celtics and New York Knicks. He also was an assistant coach for one season with the Pistsons. In 1993 he was named USA Today High School Player of the Year. Wallace was born in 1974 in Philadelphia.

Seattle Seahawks running back Ricky Watters looks to gain yardage during a preseason game Saturday, Aug. 19, 2000 in Seattle. (AP Photo/Elaine Thompson)

Ricky Watters

Watters played football at Bishop McDevitt High School and the University of Notre Dame. In the NFL, he played for the San Francisco 49ers, Philadelphia Eagles and Seattle Seahawks. He was born in 1969 in Harrisburg.

File - John Woodruff, a freshman at the University of Pittsburgh, wins the 800-meter race at the Olympic Games in Berlin, in this Aug. 8, 1936 file photo. Woodruff joined Jesse Owens as black Americans who won gold medals in the face of Adolph Hitler and his "master race" agenda at the 1936 Berlin Olympics. (AP Photo/files)

John Woodruff (1915-2007)

Woodruff won gold in the 800 meters at the 1936 Summer Olympics. He was a freshman at the University of Pittsburgh when he qualified for the Olympic team. His race was considered to be one of the most exciting in Olympic history because he got boxed in by other runners, had to stop running then came from behind to win. After school he served in the military and later became battalion commander of the 369th Artillery in the New York Army National Guard. He was born in Connellsville, Fayette County.

Guion Bluford, Jr., shuttle Challenger mission specialist, is shown in portrait on returning to the Johnson Space Center in Houston, Texas, September 5, 1983. (AP photo)

Black History Month

To learn about black Pennsylvanians you may not know and should, click here.

To read about black hip hop artists from Philadelphia, click here.
